answer_html: As we see, regardless of a and b we always find \(\mathbf{x}_1 \not= \mathbf{x}_2\).Thus using the given information, we cannot tell which solution set is correct.
answer_latex:
As we see, regardless of \emph{a} and \emph{b} we always find
$\mathbf{x}_1 \not= \mathbf{x}_2$.Thus using the given information, we
cannot tell which solution set is correct.
hints_html: If you were to solve a non-homogeneous system, would the right hand side change as you do elementary row operations? Would this affect the solution?
hints_latex:
If you were to solve a non-homogeneous system, would the right hand side
change as you do elementary row operations? Would this affect the
solution?
hints_raw: If you were to solve a non-homogeneous system, would the right hand side change as you do elementary row operations? Would this affect the solution?
question: B 03 (b)
sols_html:
No, this is not possible. Elementary row operations change the right hand side and hence, in general, solutions of Ax = b are not related to solutions of Ux = b. Only in the special case of a homogeneous system, when b = 0, is this possible.

An easy way to see this is by a counter example. We will look at two matrices A1 and A2 that can both be row reduced to U, but have different solutions to \(A\mathbf{x} = \begin{bmatrix} 1 \\ 0 \end{bmatrix}\)

Let us choose A1 = U and \(A_2 = \begin{bmatrix} 1 & 0 & -7 \\ 1 & 1 & -3 \end{bmatrix}\)

A2 was obtained by adding the first row of U to the second row of U. Hence, by subtracting row 1 from row 2 in A2 gives U, which shows that A2 can be row reduced to U.

Solving \(A_1\mathbf{x}_1 = \begin{bmatrix} 1 \\ 0 \end{bmatrix}\) we get

\[\begin{aligned} \begin{bmatrix} 1 & 0 & -7 & | & 1 \\ 0 & 1 & 4 & | & 0 \end{bmatrix}\end{aligned}\]

with solution

\[\begin{aligned} \mathbf{x}_1 = a\begin{bmatrix}7\\-4\\1\end{bmatrix} + \begin{bmatrix}1\\ 0 \\0\end{bmatrix}\end{aligned}\]

While solving \(A_2\mathbf{x}_2 = \begin{bmatrix} 1 \\ 0 \end{bmatrix}\) we get

\[\begin{aligned} \begin{bmatrix} 1 & 0 & -7 & | & 1 \\ 1 & 1 & -3 & | & 0 \end{bmatrix} \rightarrow \begin{bmatrix} 1 & 0 & -7 & | & 1 \\ 0 & 1 & 4 & | & \color{red} -1\end{bmatrix}\end{aligned}\]

with solution

\[\begin{aligned} \mathbf{x}_2 = b\begin{bmatrix}7\\-4\\1\end{bmatrix} + \begin{bmatrix}1\\ \color{red} -1\\0\end{bmatrix}\end{aligned}\]

As we see, regardless of a and b we always find \(\mathbf{x}_1 \not= \mathbf{x}_2\). Thus using the given information, we cannot tell which solution set is correct.

Another way to view this question is to notice that elementary row operations combine to give us that

\(\displaystyle A = EU\)

where E is an invertible matrix. Thus solving

\(\displaystyle Ax = \begin{bmatrix}1 \\0 \end{bmatrix}\)

Reduces to solving

\(\displaystyle Ux = E^{-1}\begin{bmatrix}1 \\0 \end{bmatrix}\)

This last solution varies with the matrix E. Notice that if the vector on the right were the zero vector, then this matrix would not matter (as it didn’t in part (a)) but here it can make a huge difference. A concrete counter example is given in solution 1.

sols_raw:
No, this is not possible. Elementary row operations change the right hand side and hence, in general, solutions of ''Ax = b'' are not related to solutions of ''Ux = b''. Only in the special case of a homogeneous system, when ''b = 0'', is this possible.

An easy way to see this is by a counter example. We will look at two matrices ''A<sub>1</sub>'' and ''A<sub>2</sub>'' that can both be row reduced to ''U'', but have different solutions to
<math> A\mathbf{x} = \begin{bmatrix} 1 \\ 0 \end{bmatrix} </math>

Let us choose ''A<sub>1</sub> = U'' and <math>
A_2 = \begin{bmatrix}
1 & 0 & -7 \\ 1 & 1 & -3
\end{bmatrix}
</math>

''A<sub>2</sub>'' was obtained by adding the first row of ''U'' to the second row of ''U''. Hence, by subtracting row 1 from row 2 in  ''A<sub>2</sub>'' gives ''U'', which shows that ''A<sub>2</sub>'' can be row reduced to ''U''.

Solving <math> A_1\mathbf{x}_1 = \begin{bmatrix} 1 \\ 0 \end{bmatrix} </math> we get
:<math>
\begin{bmatrix}
1 & 0 & -7 & | & 1 \\ 0 & 1 & 4 & | & 0
\end{bmatrix}
</math>
with solution
:<math>\mathbf{x}_1 = a\begin{bmatrix}7\\-4\\1\end{bmatrix} + \begin{bmatrix}1\\ 0 \\0\end{bmatrix}</math>

While solving <math> A_2\mathbf{x}_2 = \begin{bmatrix} 1 \\ 0 \end{bmatrix} </math> we get
:<math>
\begin{bmatrix}
1 & 0 & -7 & | & 1 \\ 1 & 1 & -3 & | & 0
\end{bmatrix} \rightarrow \begin{bmatrix}
1 & 0 & -7 & | & 1 \\ 0 & 1 & 4 & | & \color{red} -1
\end{bmatrix}
</math>
with solution

:<math>\mathbf{x}_2 = b\begin{bmatrix}7\\-4\\1\end{bmatrix} + \begin{bmatrix}1\\ \color{red} -1 \\0\end{bmatrix}</math>


As we see, regardless of ''a'' and ''b'' we always find <math> \mathbf{x}_1 \not= \mathbf{x}_2 </math>. Thus using the given information, we cannot tell which solution set is correct.
Another way to view this question is to notice that elementary row operations combine to give us that 

<math>\displaystyle 
A = EU
</math>

where ''E'' is an invertible matrix. Thus solving

<math>\displaystyle 
Ax = \begin{bmatrix}1 \\0 \end{bmatrix}
</math>

Reduces to solving 

<math>\displaystyle 
Ux = E^{-1}\begin{bmatrix}1 \\0 \end{bmatrix}
</math>

This last solution varies with the matrix ''E''. Notice that if the vector on the right were the zero vector, then this matrix would not matter (as it didn't in [[Science:Math Exam Resources/Courses/MATH152/April 2013/Question B 03 (a)|part (a)]]) but here it can make a huge difference. A concrete counter example is given in solution 1.
statement_html:
Let A be a certain \(2\times 3\) matrix. Suppose that using elementary row operations, the matrix A can be transformed into the matrix

\[\begin{aligned} U = \begin{bmatrix} 1 & 0 & -7 \\ 0 & 1 & 4 \end{bmatrix}\end{aligned}\]

Can you find the solution of \(Ax = \begin{bmatrix} 1 \\ 0 \end{bmatrix}\) with the given information? Justify your answer.
statement_raw:
Let ''A'' be a certain <math>2\times 3 </math> matrix. Suppose that using elementary row operations, the matrix ''A'' can be transformed into the matrix 

:<math>
U = \begin{bmatrix} 
1 & 0 & -7 \\
0 & 1 & 4
\end{bmatrix}
</math>

Can you find the solution of <math> Ax = \begin{bmatrix} 1 \\ 0 \end{bmatrix} </math> with the given information? Justify your answer.
